item.title: Skip functionality
item.description:
A player may simply not see the solution to a level. It is usually not hard to create a skip level mechanism.

Be creative with skip functionality, perhaps you could only show a skip button after a certain amount of attempts, or limit the skips to some per world (or even day).

item.title: Keep a to-do list
item.description: To-do lists help you keep on track by forcing you to map what you want to create. They can also be very motivating (the feeling of ticking off things you have done feels great!).

item.title: Give back
item.description:
When you got started with a particular game engine, language or tool you probably learned it by using content such as video tutorials, books, questions on stackoverflow or IRC.

Now that you do know a thing or two, consider giving back to the community by creating your own tutorial, helping rookies on the forum or open sourcing projects that others can learn from.

item.title: Do not introduce multiple mechanics in one level
item.description: Introduce your mechanics gradually throughout the game. Do not have the player combine two mechanics which are totally new to him or her.

item.title: Put your instructions in the game
item.description: A lot of players won’t read your description and instructions before playing your game. Put instructions in-game where the player first needs it.

item.title: Your game is likely too hard
item.description:
If you are creating a game, you are probably getting very good at it because you play it constantly. Have others play your game and you will see that it is much too hard for them.

Have others playtest your game during development, do not give them instructions, and learn where you can make things more manageable for first time players.

item.title: Get it done by any means
item.description:
Your small project doesn’t need a clean, robust architecture if that means you may never finish it. Focus on getting something cool and playable on the screen as soon as possible and work from there.

What matters is the resulting game, not the underlying code or tech.
